questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with left leg swelling and pain for 5 days and has a positive D-dimer test. Duplex ultrasonography confirms an extensive DVT involving the left popliteal and femoral veins. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management strategy?
questions.correct_answer: B. LMWH followed by oral anticoagulant
questions.explanation:
Venous Doppler with Duplex scanning

Non-invasive; detects thrombus by impaired blood flow and inability to compress veins.

  • Presence of echogenic material completely filling the lumen of vein
  • Absence of compressibility
  • Absence of blood flow

Venogram

Accurate for detecting and locating thrombus and differentiating occlusive and non-occlusive thrombus but less commonly used due to invasiveness.

Impedance Plethysmography

Measures changes in venous volume and flow using a cuff. Less useful for calf DVT and previous thrombosis.

Fibrin and Fibrinogen Assays

Measures fibrin degradation products, including D-dimer.

D-dimer has a high negative predictive value.

Radioactive Fibrinogen Study

Uses radiolabeled fibrinogen to detect thrombus. Less commonly used.

Magnetic Resonance Venous Imaging (MRVI)

Non-invasive; Useful for imaging iliac veins and IVC.

Initial Anticoagulation
  • Subcutaneous LMWH: Rapidly anticoagulate confirmed DVT cases.
  • Intravenous Unfractionated Heparin: For patients with significant renal impairment.
  • Fondaparinux or Bivalirudin: Alternatives for those with heparin sensitivity or heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

Transition to Oral Anticoagulation
  • Duration: At least 3 months or longer based on risk factors or recurrence.
  • Novel anticoagulants (NOACs): Rivaroxaban, Apixaban (factor Xa inhibitors), Dabigatran (direct thrombin inhibitor).
  • Vitamin K Antagonists: Warfarin (alternative to NOACs).

Monitoring Anticoagulation
  • Heparin: Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT).
  • Warfarin: INR maintained between 2.0 to 3.0.

For Patients with contraindications to Anticoagulation

Temporary IVC Filter: Consider if bleeding risk prevents anticoagulation or to prevent pulmonary embolism. It does not treat the existing thrombus and is associated with long-term complications. (Option D)

Endovascular Surgery
  • Thrombus removal, lysis, and stenting.
  • Beneficial in selected patients, especially those with iliofemoral thrombosis, to reduce risk of chronic post-thrombotic syndrome.

questions.text: An infant presents with a large, rapidly growing vascular malformation, along with severe thrombocytopenia and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Klippel-Trénaunay syndrome

Kasabach-Merritt Syndrome (KMS)
  • A mesodermal abnormality characterized by:
    • Cutaneous nevus,
    • Persistent vestigial veins with varicose veins,
    • Soft-tissue and bone hypertrophy. (Option A)
  • Segments of deep veins are hypoplastic or aplastic.
  • Possible obstruction of lymphatics.
  • Treatment:
    • Conservative management with compression stockings.
    • Removal of large superficial varicose veins done only if deep veins are patent.
  • A life-threatening coagulopathy of infancy characterized by:
    • Thrombocytopenia
    • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
    • Consumptive coagulopathy. (Option B)
  • Rapidly growing vascular tumor
  • Treatment:
    • Mainly supportive care
    • Embolization: Possible if a single feeding vessel is present.
    • Medical Therapies: Steroids,vincristine and sirolimus.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with prominent varicose veins on his medial thigh and calf. Upon examination, incompetence of the great saphenous vein (GSV) is identified. The surgeon is considering the appropriate surgical intervention. What is the primary indication for performing Saphenofemoral Junction Ligation and GSV Stripping?

options.label: A
options.text: Varicose veins on the posterolateral calf due to small saphenous vein incompetence

options.label: B
options.text: Incompetence of the great saphenous vein with varicose veins on the medial thigh and calf

options.label: C
options.text: Varicose veins on the anterior thigh due to incompetent perforator veins

options.label: D
options.text: Small varicose veins unsuitable for endovenous ablation

questions.correct_answer: B. Incompetence of the great saphenous vein with varicose veins on the medial thigh and calf
questions.explanation:
Open Surgery Procedure

Saphenofemoral Junction Ligation and Great Saphenous Vein Stripping

Indication: Used for varicose veins in the medial thigh and calf due to great saphenous vein (GSV) incompetence. (Option B) (Option C ruled out)

Procedure: An incision is made in the groin to access the saphenofemoral junction where the GSV meets the femoral vein. Tributaries of the GSV are ligated.

Stripping: The GSV is tied off at the junction, and a device is inserted into the GSV and pulled out through an incision near the knee, stripping the vein as it is removed.

Saphenopopliteal Junction Ligation and Small Saphenous Vein Stripping

Indication: Used for varicose veins on the posterolateral calf due to small saphenous vein (SSV) incompetence. (Option A ruled out)

Procedure: An incision is made to access and ligate the saphenopopliteal junction where the SSV joins the popliteal vein.

Stripping: Similar to the GSV procedure, the surgeon either strips the vein using a device or resects the proximal portion of the vein.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with chronic venous insufficiency presents with a venous ulcer on his lower leg. He has a history of prolonged standing at work and reports aching and heaviness in his legs. What is correct regarding compression therapy in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Class 1 compression hosiery exerts 18-24 mmHg of pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Compression bandaging typically exerts less pressure than compression hosiery

options.label: C
options.text: Compression bandaging should be avoided in patients with a history of venous ulcers

options.label: D
options.text: Compression therapy is most effective when it exerts a graduated pressure to promote venous return

questions.correct_answer: D. Compression therapy is most effective when it exerts a graduated pressure to promote venous return
questions.explanation:
Class

Pressure (mmHg)

Class 1

14–17 (Vs Option A)

Class 2

18–24

Class 3

25–35

Condition

ABPI

Pressure (mmHg)

Venous Ulcers (no arterial disease)

Not Applicable

35–40

Mixed Ulcers (with arterial disease)

0.5–0.8

30

Severe Arterial Compromise

<0.5 or ankle pressure < 60 mmHg

Revascularization is needed before compression

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the pathophysiology of varicose veins is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Defects in the walls or valves of the veins lead to retrograde blood flow.

options.label: B
options.text: Inflammatory changes in walls lead to dilatation, elongation and valvular dysfunction.

options.label: C
options.text: The veins have a low end-diastolic volume.

questions.correct_answer: C. The veins have a low end-diastolic volume.

questions.text: A patient comes to the surgery OPD complaining of small swellings and a wound on his right lower leg. On clinical evaluation, he is found to have hyperpigmentation in his right leg around the ankle and lower third of the leg. He also has a healed venous ulcer and is symptomatic. According to the CEAP classification, what is the clinical stage of the disease in this case?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Classification

For clinical classification:

  • No signs of venous disease
  • Telangiectasia (<1 mm) or reticular veins ( 1-3 mm dilated veins)
  • Varicose veins (>3 mm )
  • Edema
  • Pigmentation or eczema
  • LDS or atrophic blanche
  • Corona phlebectatica
  • Healed venous ulcer
  • Active venous ulcer
 

Clinical class can be further characterised as symptomatic (s), asymptomatic (a) or recurrent following previous successful treatment or healing (r), e.g. C2a, C2s, C6r.

  

C0

C1

 

C2

C3

C4a

C4b

C4c

C5

C6

For etiological classification:

  • Congenital
  • Primary
  • Secondary (post-thrombotic)
  • No venous cause identified
  

Ec

Ep

Es

En

For anatomical classification:

  • Superficial veins
  • Perforator veins
  • Deep veins
  • No venous location identified
  

As

Ap

Ad

An

For pathophysiological classification:

  • Reflux
  • Obstruction
  • Reflux and obstruction
  • No venous pathophysiology identified
  

Pr

Po

Pr,o

Pn

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with inflammatory bowel disease presents with a painful ulcer on her leg. The ulcer has a necrotic edge and a purulent base, with significant surrounding erythema. What type of ulcer is most consistent with this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Type

History

Location

Pain

Lesion Characteristics

Associated Findings

Ischemic/ arterial (Option D)

Smoking,

Intermittent claudications

Distal, on dorsum of foot or toes, over bony prominences

Severe, particularly at night; relieved by dependency

Irregular edge; poor granulation tissue, dry necrotic base; round or punched-out with sharp demarcation;

no surrounding inflammation

Trophic changes of chronic ischemia, pale, hair loss, atrophic skin, cool feet; absence of pulses, prolonged capillary refill; ankle brachial index (ABI) <0.5; dependent rubor, elevation pallor

Venous

(Option C)

Varicose veins, DVT, trauma, surgery, multiple pregnancies; aching/ swelling worse at end of day, relieved with elevation

Lower third of leg (gaiter area); between malleolus and lower calf, majority at medial malleolus

Mild; relieved by elevation

Shallow, irregular/shaggy shape; granulating base; flat or steep elevation margins; fibrinous material at ulcer bed with moderate to heavy exudate; surrounding inflammation present

Lipodermatofibrosis/ lipodermatosclerosis, pigmentation, edema, atrophie blanche; telangiectasia; normal capillary refill time, normal ankle brachial index (ABI)

Neurotrophic (Option A)

Numbness, paresthesias, burning, loss sensation in foot, Diabetes mellitus

Under calluses or pressure points (e.g., plantar aspect of first or fifth MTP joint)

None

Punched-out, with deep sinus, variable depth partial thickness to severe involving tendon, fascia, joint capsule, or bone; surrounding inflammation present

Demonstrable neuropathy, may be associated with underlying osteomyelitis

Vasculitis

History of primary or secondary connective tissue disease

Pretibial and dorsum of foot but not always geographically limited

Extremely painful

Multiple, punched-out, inflamed indurated base (pathergy phenomenon); surrounding inflammation present; surrounding skin shows reticulate vascular pattern

Fat necrosis/chronic panniculitis on pathology

Hypertensive (local infarct)

Normal pulses

Lateral malleoli

Severe

Black necrosis; surrounding inflammation present

Aka Martorell's ulcer; seen in patients with prolonged/ suboptimal controlled hypertension

Pyoderma

Gangrenosum

(Option B)

Unknown pathogenesis

Develops in sites of previous trauma, around scars, donor sites used for grafting

Severe

Non-infective ulceration with purulent base; well-defined, bluish, undermined borders; surrounding erythema; deep necrotic ulcer; surrounding inflammation present

Seen with inflammatory bowel disease, immunodeficient states, myeloma, leukemia, Behcet's syndrome

questions.text: A 62-year-old man has a chronic ulcer on his leg from a burn injury sustained 12 years ago. Recently, the ulcer has developed indurated, painless, raised edges and surrounding fibrosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Venous ulcer

Prevalence

Responsible for 85% of all chronic limb ulcers.

Causes
  • Venous disease (superficial or deep vein incompetence or obstruction)
  • Arterial ischemic ulcer
  • Vasculitic ulcer
  • Traumatic ulcer
  • Neuropathic ulcer
  • Neoplastic ulcer
  • Infections.

Pathophysiology
  • Old theories: Fibrin cuff theory and white cell trapping theory but these have not been confirmed.
  • Presently: Ambulatory venous hypertension is the primary cause.

Clinical Features
  • Gaiter's Zone: Common ulcer location around and above the medial malleoli due to numerous perforators.
  • Ulcer: Large with gently sloping edge and granulation tissue, nonhealing, tender, recurrent with secondary infections.
  • Surrounding skin often shows thickening, inflammation, induration, pigmentation (hemosiderosis) and fibrosis. (Option A)
  • Lipodermatosis: Chronic inflammation, fibrosis and thickening of the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the lower leg with pigmentation and a tight, contracted appearance, often with Achilles tendon contracture. Suggests severe chronic venous disease and gives a champagne bottle appearance.

Investigations
  • Duplex scan: To assess deep and superficial veins.
  • Biopsy: For atypical ulcers or suspected malignancy (e.g., Marjolin's ulcer).
  • Additional tests: Full blood count, blood glucose, ESR/CRP, sickle cell test, antibody screening if ulcer appears atypical.

Management
  • Compression Therapy
  • Superficial venous ablation or surgery
  • Bisgaard Method: Measures to reduce edema, increase venous drainage and promote ulcer healing
    • Elevation
    • Massage of indurated area
    • Passive and active exercise
  • Other Treatments: Pentoxifylline, horse chestnut extract, biological dressings, grafts and antibiotics.

Complications
  • Hemorrhage
  • Periostitis over tibia
  • Marjolin's Ulcer:
    • Well-differentiated ulcer (squamous cell or basal cell carcinoma) occurring in chronic scars (e.g., burn scars, venous ulcers).
    • Indurated, painless, non-tender ulcer with raised, everted edges and surrounding fibrosis. (Option C)
    • Treatment: Wide local excision
  • Infection
  • Talipes equinovarus
  • Disability

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman is scheduled for the great saphenous vein (GSV) stripping to treat her varicose veins. What is the most likely nerve injury she might experience post-operatively?

A patient with chronic venous insufficiency presents with symptomatic varicose veins. The physician decides to use foam sclerotherapy, specifically the Tessari technique, to treat the affected veins. What is the typical ratio of sclerosant to air used in the Tessari technique for creating the foam?
questions.explanation:
Sclerotherapy
  • A sclerosing agent, typically sodium tetradecyl sulphate, is injected into the affected vein.
  • This agent damages the vein lining, causing it to collapse and eventually be absorbed by the body.
  • To enhance the effectiveness of the sclerosant, it is mixed with air to create a foam.
  • This foam allows for greater contact with the vein wall and displaces blood that could inactivate the sclerosant

Indications: Telangiectasias, reticular veins, and small, nonaxial varicose veins (<6 mm) visible in chronic venous disease; suitable for patients with persistent symptoms despite medical management.

Aspect

Tessari Technique

Sclerosants

Indications and Contraindications

Foam Preparation
  • Two syringes: one with sclerosant, one with air/gas (CO2)
  • Connected via multi-way stopcock.
  • Sclerosant to air ratio is usually 1:3 or 1:4
 
  • Repeated plunger action to create foam
  • STS: Synthetic sodium salt with anesthetic properties
  • Polidocanol: Synthetic polyethylene glycol, also an anesthetic.
  • Effective for telangiectasias, reticular veins
  • HTS: 23% hypertonic saline, osmotic agent
  • Candidates: Asymptomatic patients and those with controlled recent or recurrent venous bleeding may undergo sclerotherapy without additional diagnostics.
  • Contraindications: Avoid sclerotherapy during acute venous thrombosis or pregnancy.
  • Risks: Microembolism risk
  • Vessel Size: Suitable for veins up to 6 mm in diameter, including small, nonaxial varicose veins, reticular veins, and telangiectasias.

Injection Technique
  • Downstream injection from larger to smaller veins.
 
  • Controlled foam volume to displace blood.

Advantages
  • Minimally invasive, enhanced efficacy, safety profile.
  • Reduced volume requirement due to foam.
  • STS: Rapid clearance in blood, effective for larger veins.
  • Polidocanol: Decreased risk of thrombosis, suitable for smaller veins.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the difference between Dodd and Cockett surgeries?

options.label: A
options.text: Dodd: ligation in the thigh; Cockett: ligation in the lower leg

options.label: C
options.text: Dodd: targets superficial veins; Cockett: targets deep veins

options.label: D
options.text: Dodd: higher risk of nerve injury; Cockett: lower risk

questions.correct_answer: A. Dodd: ligation in the thigh; Cockett: ligation in the lower leg
questions.explanation:
Surgery

Purpose

Technique

Advantages

Current Relevance

SEPS (Subfascial Endoscopic Perforator Vein Surgery)

Treats chronic venous insufficiency by targeting incompetent perforator veins.

Minimally invasive; uses an endoscope to access and clip/divide perforator veins.

Less pain, shorter recovery, fewer complications.

Preferred over open surgery; effective in preventing venous ulcers.

Dodd Surgery

Addresses incompetent perforator veins in the thigh.

Open surgery; incision made to ligate or divide thigh perforator veins (Dodd perforators).

Direct access to perforator veins.

Less common due to SEPS; historically significant.

Cockett Surgery

Targets incompetent perforator veins in the lower leg.

Open surgery; incision over the lower leg to ligate perforator veins near the medial malleolus (Cockett perforators).

Direct access to lower leg perforator veins.

Less common due to SEPS; historically significant.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with symptomatic varicose veins. She is interested in learning about the available treatment options and their benefits. Her primary concern is to minimize recovery time and reduce post-operative pain. Which of the following surgical approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Saphenofemoral ligation and great saphenous stripping

options.label: B
options.text: Saphenopopliteal junction ligation and small saphenous stripping

questions.explanation:
Aspect

Endovenous Laser Ablation (EVLA)

Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA)

Procedure Overview
  • Minimally invasive, uses laser energy to close incompetent veins.
  • Gold standard and has largely replaced surgical ligation and stripping.
  • Minimally invasive, uses radiofrequency energy to close veins

Indications

Treats incompetent truncal veins, often used for varicose veins

Treats incompetent truncal veins, similar to EVLA

Advantages
  • High efficacy (>95% closure rate)
  • Cost-effective
  • Versatile (treats large and small veins)
  • Effective for tortuous veins
  • Standard fibers treat perforator veins
  • High efficacy (>95% closure rate)
  • Standardized treatment cycles
  • Potentially reduced post-procedural pain and bruising
  • Simplified procedural setup without laser safety protocols

Applications
  • Varicose veins
  • Venous ulcer treatment, when combined with compression therapy
  • Varicose veins

Key Differences
  • Laser energy used for vein ablation
  • Requires laser safety protocols
  • Radiofrequency energy used for vein ablation
  • Automated energy delivery simplifies the procedure

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with chronic leg pain, swelling, and visible varicose veins. A duplex ultrasound is performed to assess venous function. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding interpreting the duplex scan in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: The duplex scan should be performed with the patient in a supine position

options.label: B
options.text: A reflux time of less than 500 milliseconds is clinically significant

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of perforator vein with a diameter >3.5 mm is significant

options.label: D
options.text: The duplex scan is primarily used to locate perforating veins

questions.correct_answer: C. Presence of perforator vein with a diameter >3.5 mm is significant
questions.explanation:
Parameter

Significance

Position during Scan

Standing or trunk-elevated (NOT supine)

Reflux Time (≥ 500 ms)

Indicative of significant reflux

Perforator Vein Diameter (> 3.5 mm)

Suggestive of significant perforator reflux

Primary Use of Duplex Scan

Assess venous reflux, NOT locating perforators

questions.text: The following test was conducted in the clinic for a patient suffering from varicose veins. On releasing only tourniquet 3, the filling of blood was observed. What does this signify?

A patient with varicose veins is being examined in the surgical OPD. The Brodie-Trendelenburg I test is done for the patient, and the surgeon notices that blood is filling from above. What does this signify?

A 45-year-old man presents with left leg swelling and pain for 3 days. Duplex ultrasonography reveals a thrombus in the popliteal vein. Which of the following veins is most likely to be involved next in the progression of this DVT?

After noticing small swellings over his legs, a 60-year-old man comes to the surgical OPD. He is a tailor by occupation and works long hours. He explains that he experiences a heaviness and aching in the legs after a long day of work but is relieved once he elevates his legs and rests. Which of the following is not a more severe sign of this disease?

A 50-year-old woman presents with visible, dilated veins on both legs. She has a history of two pregnancies and works as a retail clerk. On examination, the dilated veins are most prominent along the posterior aspect of her calves. Which of the following describes the classification of her varicose veins based on the involved venous system?

A 55-year-old woman presents with varicose veins in her left leg. On examination, you notice dilated, tortuous veins along the posterior aspect of her calf and lateral thigh. To accurately map the incompetent veins for potential treatment, which of the following describes the most likely location of the Boyd perforator vein?

options.label: A
options.text: Medial ankle, posterior to the medial malleolus

options.label: B
options.text: Medial calf, approximately 10 cm above the medial malleolus

options.label: C
options.text: Lateral calf, at the junction of the middle and lower thirds

options.label: D
options.text: Medial knee, approximately 10 cm below the knee joint line

questions.correct_answer: D. Medial knee, approximately 10 cm below the knee joint line

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of tender, erythematous cord-like swellings along different superficial veins of her lower extremities over the past 3 months. Which of the following is most likely to be associated with this presentation?

A 20-year-old competitive swimmer presents with a 2-day history of left arm pain, swelling, and mild discoloration after intense training. Duplex ultrasound shows a thrombus in the left subclavian vein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Upper Extremity DVT

  • Less common than lower extremity DVT, comprising ~5% of all DVT cases.
  • Serious condition with a risk of pulmonary embolism in up to one-third of cases.
  • Typically involves thrombosis of the axillary or subclavian veins.

Categories

Primary Idiopathic:

  • Idiopathic upper extremity DVT
    • Idiopathic cases warrant evaluation for occult malignancy.
  • Paget-Schroetter syndrome (Option B)
    • Effort induced thrombosis due to subclavian vein compression.
    • Often seen in young athletes with repetitive upper extremity motion (e.g., swimming).
    • Anatomic anomalies like cervical ribs or myofascial bands can cause venous compression.
    • It may develop as a sequale of thoracic outlet syndrome
    • Diagnosis may involve plain films to confirm thoracic outlet syndrome (as shown in the image below).
    • Treatment: Initial thrombolysis followed by thoracic outlet decompression (first rib and scalene muscle resection).
    • Surgical approach: Reconstruction of axillary and subclavian veins.
    • Post-surgery: Anticoagulation for 6-12 months.

Secondary:

  • More common
  • Due to indwelling central venous catheters, pacemakers, thrombophilia or malignant disease.

Clinical Findings
  • Unilateral swelling
  • Pain
  • Extremity discomfort
  • Erythema
  • Palpable cord

Diagnosis

  • Duplex ultrasonography
  • Venography or magnetic resonance venography

Treatment

  • Anticoagulation therapy: Heparin or LMWH plus warfarin for at least 3 months is the mainstay of treatment.
  • Thrombolysis does not significantly reduce long-term manifestations.

Complication

  • Recurrence
  • Post-thrombotic syndrome (PTS)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is in the post-operative ward after a cesarean section. She had no complications and gave birth to a healthy baby. Which of the following is a prophylactic step she needs to be advised to prevent deep vein thrombosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Early mobilization along with compression stockings

questions.correct_answer: A. Early mobilization along with compression stockings
questions.explanation:
Level of risk

Suggested thromboprophylaxis options

Very low-risk

General or abdominopelvic surgery
  • No specific thromboprophylaxis
  • Early ambulation along with compression stockings (Option A)

Low risk

General or abdominopelvic surgery
  • Mechanical prophylaxis
  • Early ambulation and mechanical device (compression stockings)

Moderate risk

General or abdominopelvic surgery
  • LMWH (at recommended doses) (Option B)
  • LDUH (Option C) or mechanical prophylaxis

High bleeding risk
  • Mechanical prophylaxis
  • Early ambulation and mechanical device( compression stockings

High risk

General or abdominopelvic surgery
  • LMWH (at recommended doses),
  • fondaparinux (Option D), and mechanical prophylaxis

High bleeding risk

General or abdominopelvic surgery for cancer
  • Mechanical thromboprophylaxis
  • Extended-duration LMWH (4 weeks)

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of discoloration of his left leg as shown in the image. He has a history of deep vein thrombosis and has been inconsistent on medication. What is the possible diagnosis here?

A 45-year-old man with metastatic colorectal cancer is diagnosed with an acute DVT of the left leg. He had an episode of upper GI bleed 2 days ago. His lab results show a platelet count of 40,000/μL and an INR of 1.8. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for preventing pulmonary embolism in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Place a retrievable IVC filter
questions.explanation:
IVC Filters:

Mechanical devices designed to prevent pulmonary embolism by trapping large clots in the inferior vena cava.

Indications

  • Recurrent thromboembolism despite adequate anticoagulation
  • Deep venous thrombosis in a patient with contraindications to anticoagulation
  • Chronic pulmonary embolism and resultant pulmonary hypertension
  • Complications of anticoagulation
  • Propagating iliofemoral venous thrombus in anticoagulation

Types

Two main types of IVC filters:

  • Permanent filters: Designed for lifelong use
  • Retrievable (temporary) filters: Can be removed when no longer needed
    • Retrievable filters offer the flexibility of removal once the risk of pulmonary embolism has decreased or anticoagulation becomes feasible.
    • This approach helps mitigate the long-term complications associated with permanent filters.

Indications of Retrievable IVC Filter
  • Prophylactic placement in high-risk trauma patients (orthopedic, spinal cord patients)
  • Short-term duration, contraindication to anticoagulation therapy
  • Protection during venous thrombolytic therapy
  • Extensive iliocaval thrombosis

Complication

  • Migration or embolization of the filter
  • Fracture of the filter
  • Perforation of the IVC or adjacent structures
  • IVC thrombosis
  • Post-thrombotic syndrome

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of colorectal cancer underwent surgery 3 weeks ago and is now presenting with complaints of left leg swelling and pain for 3 days. His left calf is 4 cm larger than the right. Using Wells' criteria for DVT, what is his pre-test probability score and risk category?
questions.explanation:
Variable

Score

Lower limb trauma or surgery or immobilization in a plaster cast

1

Bedridden for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks

1

Tenderness along the line of femoral or popliteal veins

1

Entire limb swollen

1

Calf >3 cm larger circumference than another side 10 cm below the tibial tuberosity

1

Pitting oedema

1

Dilated collateral superficial veins (not varicose veins)

1

Previous DVT

1

Malignancy (including treatment up to 6 months ago)

1

Intravenous drug abuse

3

Alternative diagnosis more likely than DVT

-2

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with a swollen, painful left calf that developed over the past two days. He reports no history of trauma, surgery, or prolonged immobility. Physical examination reveals a warm, erythematous, and tender left calf. Which of the following clinical features is most specific for diagnosing deep vein thrombosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Calf pain on dorsiflexion of the foot

options.label: C
options.text: Pain that worsens with leg elevation

options.label: D
options.text: Localized tenderness along the course of the deep veins

questions.correct_answer: D. Localized tenderness along the course of the deep veins
questions.explanation:
Clinical Feature

Significance

1. Localized tenderness

Specific for DVT; indicates inflammation along the vein.

2. Asymmetrical calf swelling

Common but not specific to DVT.

3. Erythema and warmth

Suggestive of inflammation or thrombosis.

4. Pain in the affected limb

Can occur with or without movement; can indicate venous obstruction.

5. Dilated superficial veins

May indicate compensatory circulation due to deep venous obstruction.

6. Homans' sign

Non-specific; Passive forceful dorsiflexion of the foot with extended knee will cause tenderness in the calf.

7. Mose’s sign

Painful response to gentle squeezing of the lower calf from side-to-side.

8. Neuhof's Sign

Thickening and deep tenderness in the calf muscles upon palpation.

9. Phlegmasia Alba Dolens

DVT of the femoral vein causes painful congestion and edema of the leg with lymphangitis, which further increases edema (white leg).

10. Phlegmasia Caerulea Dolens

Extensive DVT in iliac and pelvic veins leading to a blue leg with possible venous gangrene or infarction.
